title: | Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence
text: Assessing the Likelihood of Neurodevelopmental Conditions After Birth with Oxytocin: A Living Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

title: | Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence
text:
Abstract
This living meta-analysis investigates the relationship between perinatal exposure to exogenous oxytocin and the likelihood of neurodevelopmental conditions such as attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and autism in children. Oxytocin is commonly used to induce and augment labor, with up to 50% of births in developed countries and varying rates (0.7% to 97.0%) in low- and lower-middle-income countries associated with synthetic oxytocin use.
The analysis employs a frequentist approach, utilizing random effects models with the Paule-Mandel estimator to synthesize findings across the literature. The project addresses whether perinatal exposure to exogenous oxytocin increases the likelihood of neurodevelopmental conditions in children. This living meta-analysis will be updated every 24 months, ensuring the incorporation of emerging evidence.

title: | Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence
text:
Current Results
This is a pre-registered protocol. Initial analysis has not yet been conducted. Results will be posted when the analysis is completed and the pre-print is published.
A previous meta-analysis by L√∏nfeldt and colleagues (2019) concluded that there was no evidence for an association between perinatal exogenous oxytocin exposure and the later diagnosis of ADHD and only marginal evidence for an association with autism. This living meta-analysis will update those findings with new research.

title: | Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence
text:
Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria

Inclusion Criteria

Type of Studies: Original research written in English
Exposure: Perinatal synthetic oxytocin exposure
Outcomes: Any childhood neurodevelopmental outcome listed in DSM-5 or ICD-10 (including F-diagnoses and supplementary somatic diagnoses for delayed development: R41.8, R62, R62.0, R62.9)
Outcomes: Dimensional measures of psychiatric symptom severity
Data Requirements: Must report a risk estimate or data that would enable calculation of a risk estimate (e.g., frequencies or percentages)



Exclusion Criteria

Studies that describe pharmacological induction without specifying the use of synthetic oxytocin
In cases of publications using the same sample and outcomes, later publications will be excluded

title: | Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence
text:
Methodology Summary
This living meta-analysis follows the PRISMA guidelines for systematic reviews. Our methodology is pre-registered and will incorporate data from the previous meta-analysis by L√∏nfeldt and colleagues (2019) as well as relevant data published since then.
The quality of included studies will be assessed using the modified Newcastle-Ottawa Quality Assessment Scales (NOS) for case-control and cohort studies. Studies will be independently rated by two reviewers within three categories: selection, comparability, and exposure/outcome, with scores categorized as low (0‚Äì3), moderate (4‚Äì7), or high (8‚Äì11) quality.
Statistical analyses will be conducted using R statistical software with the metafor, meta, and RoBMA packages. Random effects models will be used with the Paule-Mandel estimator for œÑ¬≤. Heterogeneity will be evaluated by calculating I¬≤ and œÑ¬≤. Publication bias will be assessed using Robust Bayesian Meta-Analysis (RoBMA) and by constructing contour-enhanced funnel plot visualization and performing Egger‚Äôs regression test.

title: | Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence
text:
Update Protocol
This is a living meta-analysis that will be updated every 24 months for a minimum of six years (three updates after initial publication). Updates will include:

New database searches using the original search strategy
Screening of new studies using identical inclusion/exclusion criteria
Data extraction and quality assessment following pre-registered protocols
Updated analysis incorporating all eligible studies
Application of a conservative Bonferroni correction for four tests (p = 0.01 threshold for statistical significance)


Updates Log

Initial pre-registration: 2023
First analysis and publication: Pending



Next Update
Scheduled for: 24 months after initial publication

title: How to Publish Your Living Meta-Analysis on AMORE
text:
AMORE workflow 
    
    
      
        1
        Propose Your Topic
      
      
        2
        Steering Committee Review
      
      
        3
        Pre-registration
      
      
        4
        Conduct Review
      
      
        5
        Data Deposit
      
      
        6
        Publication
      
      
        7
        Regular Updates
      
    
  

  
    
    
      Step 1: Propose Your Topic
      
        Contact us
        
        If you want to publish your living meta-analysis on the AMORE platform then you can contact us through our contact form. There is no commitment in reaching out, and we will answer questions about conducting analysis, our standardization framework or preparing protocols. The contact form will redirect you to the right form for project proposal or questions. 
        
        What to include:
        
          A meta-analysis investigating oxytocin related to a biobehavioral outcome
          Living meta-analysis update frequency (maximum 24 months between updates)
          Proposal of protocol within our standardization framework. The necessary information we need for evaluating if your meta-analysis project can be implemented on AMORE is found as a checklist on the resources page
        
      
    

    
    
      Step 2: Steering Committee Review
      
        Review Process
        
          Evaluation that living meta-analysis is within platform remit
          Confirmation that topic is suitable for inclusion
          Verification that all mandatory requirements from checklist are met
          Methodological review and advice if needed
        
      
    

    
    
      Step 3: Pre-registration
      
        Registration Requirements
        
          Pre-register in recognised repository (e.g. Open Science Framework, PROSPERO)
          Project will be added to AMORE homepage with its own project page
        
      
    
    
    
    
      Step 4: Conduct Review
      
        Perform systematic review
        
          Conduct review based on pre-registered protocol
          Analyses must be performed on free software for reproducibility
          Track any deviations from protocol and document in deviation report
        
      
    

    
    
      Step 5: Data Deposit
      
        Data Requirements
        
          Deposit complete dataset in recognized repository (e.g. Open Science Framework or Zenodo) 
          Deposit free software script in recognised repository
          Provide deviation report as supplementary material to analysis script
        
      
    

    
    
      Step 6: Publication
      
        Publication Process
        
          Publish manuscript on recognized pre-print server (e.g., Open Science Framework)
          Submit to peer-reviewed journal
          Project page will be updated with links to:
          
            Pre-print
            Published paper
            Deviation report
          
          Ensure all documentation remains accessible
        
      
    

    
    
      Step 7: Regular Updates
      
        Update Requirements
        
          Conduct new searches according to update plan
          Maximum time between updates: 24 months
          For each update:
          
            Document all changes
            Remove any retracted papers
            Update all relevant materials
            Maintain accessibility of all documents
          
          Follow original protocol for consistency

title: Research tools and resources
text:
Additional Resources


PRISMA for Living Systematic Reviews
PRISMA for Living Systematic Reviews (LSR) is an extension of the PRISMA statement that provides guidance on reporting living systematic reviews and meta-analyses. It includes a checklist and flow diagram to help researchers ensure they are following best practices in their reporting.
Visit PRISMA-Statement.org Website


PROSPERO
PROSPERO is specifically designed for registering systematic review protocols focused on health related research It provides a standardized format for documenting review methods before they begin.
Visit PROSPERO


Open Science Framework (OSF)
The Open Science Framework (OSF) is a free and open-source platform that supports researchers in managing their projects, sharing their data, and collaborating with others. It provides tools for pre-registration, data sharing, and project management, making it easier for researchers to conduct and share their work transparently. It is developed by the Center for Open Science (COS).
Visit OSF


Retraction Watch
Tracking retractions as a window into the scientific process. This resource monitors and reports on retractions of scientific papers.
Visit Retraction Watch


Zotero
Reference management software that helps you collect, organize, and cite research. Zotero informs when articles in your libraries have been retracted or corrected, and it can help you keep track of your references and citations.
Visit Zotero

title: Protocol checklist
text:
This protocol checklist tool serves to help ensure all necessary information in the project proposal form is included. When planning your project use this checklist to see what information we require. This will streamline the process of entering the required details to the ‚Äúpropose your project‚Äù form when you are ready to submit your project proposal.


  
    Download Checklist as PDF
  

  Project Information
  
    
      Project title
    
    
  
  
    
      Abstract
      The form requires an abstract of no more than 250 words
    
    
  
  
    
      Research question
      The form requires you to state your primary research question(s)
    
    
  

  Mandatory Requirements
  
    
      Update frequency of your living meta-analysis
      AMORE's standardized framework allows a maximum time between updates of 24 months. In the "propose your project" form, you must specify your planned update frequency for your living meta-analysis.
    
    
  
  
    
      Preregistration plan
      AMORE's standardized framework requires your living meta-analysis to be preregistered to a recognized repository. In the "propose your project" form, you must specify what recognised platform you will preregister to or provide an existing registration link.
    
    
  
  
    
      Preprint plan
      AMORE's standardized framework requires initial results to be published to a recognized preprint server. In the "propose your project" form, researchers are required to describe their plan to publish the initial results to a recognized preprint server.
    
    
  
  
    
      Guidelines adherence
      AMORE's standardized framework requires adherence to recognized reporting guidelines. In the "propose your project" form, you must specify which reporting guidelines (e.g., PRISMA, MOOSE, MARS, or others) your meta-analysis will follow.
    
    
  
  
    
      Data repository plan
      AMORE's standardized framework requires meta-analysis data to be stored in a recognized repository. In the "propose your project" form, you must specify which repository (e.g., Open Science Framework, Zenodo) you will use to store your meta-analysis data.
    
    
  
  
    
      Analysis software and repository
      AMORE's standardized framework requires the use of free software for analyses, and for the analyses scripts to be deposited in a recognised repository. In the "propose your project" form, you must specify which free software you will use for your meta-analysis and specify which repository.
    
    
  
  
    
      Deviation reporting
      AMORE's standardized framework require reporting any deviations from the preregistered protocol. In the "propose your project" form, you must indicate whether you will provide a deviation report with your meta-analysis manuscript.
    
    
  

  Recommended Practices
  
    
      Addressing accumulation bias
      Living meta-analyses introduce the issue of multiple testing and increased type 1 error. In the "propose your project" form, you must indicate whether you plan to address this issue if using a frequentist framework.
    
    
  
  
    
      Effect determination with Bayes Factor
      For Bayesian meta-analyses, AMORE recommends a Bayes factor of 10 to conclude the presence or absence of an effect. In the "propose your project" form, please specify the Bayes factor you will use to determine the presence or absence of an effect if you are performing a bayesian meta-analyses.
    
    
  
  
    
      Null hypothesis evaluation
      AMORE recognizes that evaluating evidence for a null hypothesis is critical for falsifying hypotheses. In the "propose your project" form, please specify if and how you plan to evaluate evidence for a null hypothesis if performing a frequentist meta-analysis.
    
    
  
  
    
      Visualizations
      Visualization can enhance understanding of meta-analysis results. In the "propose your project" form, you may describe which visualizations (e.g., funnel plots, forest plots, others) you plan to include in your meta-analysis.

title: | Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence
text:
Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence

AMORE is a online platform that hosts living meta-analysis for oxytocin research investigating biobehavioral outcomes. AMORE serves as a central hub connecting documentation stored in recognized external repositories with their respective meta-analysis, making research easily accessible.
Living meta-analysis published on AMORE must adhere to our standardization framework, which includes both mandatory requirements and recommended practices. A key requirement is that all analyses must be updated at least every 24 months to reflect current evidence in the field.

Publish your Living Meta Analysis

title: | Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence
text:
Aims of AMORE



AMORE aims to facilitate living meta analysis in the oxytocin research field through standardized practices.



Living meta-analysis is a regularly updated evidence synthesis that reflects the current state of research. AMORE aims to ensure that the evidence remains current, preventing meta-analyses from becoming outdated.



Living meta-analysis published on AMORE commit to transparency through pre-registration, open data, and publicly available analysis scripts.

title: Title of your Living meta analysis
text:
Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria

Inclusion Criteria

Participants: Healthy adults (18-65 years)
Intervention: Intranasal oxytocin administration (single dose 24-40 IU)
Comparator: Placebo-controlled
Outcomes: Standardized measures of prosocial behavior or trust
Study Design: Randomized controlled trials with between-subjects design
Publication Type: Peer-reviewed articles and preprints
Language: Any language with English abstract



Exclusion Criteria

Participants: Studies with clinical populations (psychiatric or neurological disorders)
Animal studies
Measurment: Studies using endogenous oxytocin measurement only
Study design: Case studies and non-experimental designs
Effect sizes: Studies without available effect size data or sufficient information to calculate effect sizes

title: | Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence
section: What is the AMORE initiative about?
text:
What is the AMORE initiative about?
The Active Monitoring of Oxytocin Research Evidence (AMORE) platform serves as a living meta-analysis hub for oxytocin research related to biobehavioral outcomes. Living meta analysis is a tool to better understand findings of individual studies and place them in a bigger evidence picture. Whereas traditional meta-analysis becomes outdated, living meta analysis are regularly updated. Retracted papers can be removed and newly published papers can be included in the analysis. This ensures that the newest evidence is reflected in the living meta-analysis.

Aims of AMORE



1


Real-time insights
Researchers get access to the most current understanding of oxytocin research findings. Unlike traditional meta-analyses that become outdated, our platform continuously incorporates new research findings.




2


Quality Control
The expert steering committe oversees the projects ensuring platform standards. Retracted papers are promptly removed, ensuring only reliable evidence informs our conclusions.




3


Transparent Science
Living meta-analysis published on AMORE commit to transparency through pre-registration, pre-prints, open data, deviation reports, and publicly available analysis scripts. Transparent research foster collaboration and repoducibility efforts.

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Abstract
This preregistered systematic review and meta-analysis investigates the effects of oxytocin administration on non-social executive functions in humans. While oxytocin has received considerable attention for its role in social behaviors, emerging evidence suggests broader cognitive effects beyond social contexts.
The analysis employed both frequentist and Bayesian approaches, synthesizing 20 effect estimates from 13 eligible studies (729 total participants). The project addresses whether oxytocin administration influences executive functions when measured using non-social stimuli and tasks. A multilevel random-effects meta-analysis was conducted to account for multiple outcomes within studies.

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Current Results
The meta-analysis found no overall significant effect of oxytocin administration on non-social executive functions (Hedges‚Äô g = 0.07, 95% CI [-0.07, 0.22], p = 0.30). However, subgroup analyses revealed significant heterogeneity across different executive function domains.
Key Findings:

Cognitive Flexibility: Significant positive effect (Hedges‚Äô g = 0.20, p = 0.02)
Working Memory: No significant effect (Hedges‚Äô g = 0.05)
Inhibitory Control: No significant effect (Hedges‚Äô g = -0.04)

The Robust Bayesian Meta-Analysis provided moderate support for the absence of an overall effect (BF‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ = 0.10) and moderate evidence against publication bias (BF_PB = 0.32). Statistical power analyses indicated that individual studies were generally underpowered (5-10% power) to detect the observed summary effect size.

Statistical Power Analysis



Firepower Plot


Figure 2: Firepower plot. Statistical power of the main meta-analysis obtained by calculating the median power for effect sizes ranging from Hedges‚Äô g = 0.1‚Äì1 across all studies included in the meta-analysis. The analysis shows that individual studies had very low statistical power (median 6%) to detect the observed summary effect size.

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria

Inclusion Criteria

Type of Studies: Human studies measuring effects of oxytocin administration on executive function using non-social stimuli
Intervention: Oxytocin administered intranasally, orally, or intravenously regardless of dosage
Population: Both clinical and neurotypical participants (no age restrictions)
Outcomes: Executive function measures (working memory, inhibitory control, cognitive flexibility) using non-social stimuli such as abstract shapes
Design: Placebo-controlled studies
Language: Publications in English language
Data Requirements: Sufficient statistical information to calculate effect sizes



Exclusion Criteria

Non-human animal studies
Studies investigating only endogenous oxytocin levels (no administration)
Studies measuring only somatic functions
Executive function tasks using social stimuli (e.g., emotional faces, social scenarios)
Studies without placebo control conditions
Insufficient statistical data for meta-analysis

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Methodology Summary
This preregistered systematic review followed PRISMA guidelines. Searches were conducted in PubMed, Europe PubMed Central, and Bielefeld Academic Search Engine (BASE) on July 29, 2022, with an updated search on August 1, 2023.
Quality assessment was conducted using the RoB 2.0 tool for assessing risk of bias in randomized trials. Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed study quality, with disagreements resolved through discussion.
Statistical analyses were implemented in R Studio 4.2.2 using the metafor package for frequentist meta-analysis and RoBMA for Robust Bayesian Meta-Analysis. A multilevel random-effects model was used to account for multiple dependent outcomes from the same studies. Between-measurement correlation was set at r = 0.3 based on available raw data from one included study.

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Search Strategy

PubMed: Search terms developed with assistance from academic librarians, targeting oxytocin administration studies with executive function outcomes
Europe PubMed Central: Customized search terms adapted for database specifications
Bielefeld Academic Search Engine (BASE): Comprehensive search strategy including grey literature and preprints

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Study Characteristics

Included studies: The final meta-analysis included 13 studies with 20 effect estimates
Total participants: 729 (284 in within-participant studies, 445 in between-group studies)
Mean age: 31.64 years (within-participant studies), 25.68 years (between-group studies)
Oxytocin dosage: Predominantly 24 IU intranasal (76.92% of studies)
Administration routes: Intranasal (92.3%), oral (7.7%)
Publication status: 76.92% peer-reviewed articles, 23.07% letters to editor
Study designs: 6 within-participant, 7 between-group studies

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Key Limitations and Future Directions
Study Limitations: - Male-dominated samples (consistent with broader oxytocin literature bias) - Generally underpowered individual studies - Heterogeneity in outcome measures across executive function domains - Limited number of studies for some subgroup analyses
Future Research Needs: 1. Larger, adequately powered studies 2. Greater inclusion of female participants 3. Standardized outcome measures for executive function assessment 4. Investigation of dose-response relationships 5. Exploration of individual difference moderators
The findings suggest that oxytocin‚Äôs effects may be more nuanced than previously thought, with specific benefits for cognitive flexibility rather than executive function broadly. This aligns with the allostatic theory of oxytocin, which proposes that oxytocin facilitates adaptive responses to environmental changes.

      Step 1: Propose Your Topic
      
        Contact us
        
        If you want to publish your living meta-analysis on the AMORE platform then you can contact us through our contact form. There is no commitment in reaching out, and we will answer questions about conducting analysis, our standardization framework or preparing protocols. The contact form will redirect you to the right form for project proposal or questions. 
        
        What to include:
        
          A meta-analysis investigating oxytocin related to a biobehavioral outcome
          Living meta-analysis update frequency (maximum 24 months between updates)
          Proposal of protocol within our standardization framework. The necessary information we need for evaluating if your meta-analysis project can be implemented on AMORE is found as a checklist on the resources page
        
      
    

    
    
      Step 2: Steering Committee Review
      
        Review Process
        
          Evaluation that living meta-analysis is within platform remit
          Confirmation that topic is suitable for inclusion
          Verification that all mandatory requirements from checklist are met
          Methodological review and advice if needed
        
      
    

    
    
      Step 3: Pre-registration
      
        Registration Requirements
        
          Pre-register in recognised repository (e.g. Open Science Framework, PROSPERO)
          Project will be added to AMORE homepage with its own project page
        
      
    
    
    
    
      Step 4: Conduct Review
      
        Perform systematic review
        
          Conduct review based on pre-registered protocol
          Analyses must be performed on free software for reproducibility
          Track any deviations from protocol and document in deviation report
        
      
    

    
    
      Step 5: Data Deposit
      
        Data Requirements
        
          Deposit complete dataset in recognized repository (e.g. Open Science Framework or Zenodo) 
          Deposit free software script in recognised repository
          Provide deviation report as supplementary material to analysis script
        
      
    

    
    
      Step 6: Publication
      
        Publication Process
        
          Publish manuscript on recognized pre-print server (e.g., Open Science Framework)
          Submit to peer-reviewed journal
          Project page will be updated with links to:
          
            Pre-print
            Published paper
            Deviation report
          
          Ensure all documentation remains accessible
        
      
    

    
    
      Step 7: Regular Updates
      
        Update Requirements
        
          Conduct new searches according to update plan
          Maximum time between updates: 24 months
          For each update:
          
            Document all changes
            Remove any retracted papers
            Update all relevant materials
            Maintain accessibility of all documents
          
          Follow original protocol for consistency

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Abstract
This preregistered systematic review and meta-analysis investigates the effects of oxytocin administration on non-social executive functions in humans. While oxytocin has received considerable attention for its role in social behaviors, emerging evidence suggests broader cognitive effects beyond social contexts.
The analysis employed both frequentist and Bayesian approaches, synthesizing 20 effect estimates from 13 eligible studies (729 total participants). The project addresses whether oxytocin administration influences executive functions when measured using non-social stimuli and tasks. A multilevel random-effects meta-analysis was conducted to account for multiple outcomes within studies.

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Current Results
The meta-analysis found no overall significant effect of oxytocin administration on non-social executive functions (Hedges‚Äô g = 0.07, 95% CI [-0.07, 0.22], p = 0.30). However, subgroup analyses revealed significant heterogeneity across different executive function domains.
Key Findings:

Cognitive Flexibility: Significant positive effect (Hedges‚Äô g = 0.20, p = 0.02)
Working Memory: No significant effect (Hedges‚Äô g = 0.05)
Inhibitory Control: No significant effect (Hedges‚Äô g = -0.04)

The Robust Bayesian Meta-Analysis provided moderate support for the absence of an overall effect (BF‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ = 0.10) and moderate evidence against publication bias (BF_PB = 0.32). Statistical power analyses indicated that individual studies were generally underpowered (5-10% power) to detect the observed summary effect size.

Statistical Power Analysis



Firepower Plot


Figure 2: Firepower plot. Statistical power of the main meta-analysis obtained by calculating the median power for effect sizes ranging from Hedges‚Äô g = 0.1‚Äì1 across all studies included in the meta-analysis. The analysis shows that individual studies had very low statistical power (median 6%) to detect the observed summary effect size.

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria

Inclusion Criteria

Type of Studies: Human studies measuring effects of oxytocin administration on executive function using non-social stimuli
Intervention: Oxytocin administered intranasally, orally, or intravenously regardless of dosage
Population: Both clinical and neurotypical participants (no age restrictions)
Outcomes: Executive function measures (working memory, inhibitory control, cognitive flexibility) using non-social stimuli such as abstract shapes
Design: Placebo-controlled studies
Language: Publications in English language
Data Requirements: Sufficient statistical information to calculate effect sizes



Exclusion Criteria

Non-human animal studies
Studies investigating only endogenous oxytocin levels (no administration)
Studies measuring only somatic functions
Executive function tasks using social stimuli (e.g., emotional faces, social scenarios)
Studies without placebo control conditions
Insufficient statistical data for meta-analysis

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Methodology Summary
This preregistered systematic review followed PRISMA guidelines. Searches were conducted in PubMed, Europe PubMed Central, and Bielefeld Academic Search Engine (BASE) on July 29, 2022, with an updated search on August 1, 2023.
Quality assessment was conducted using the RoB 2.0 tool for assessing risk of bias in randomized trials. Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed study quality, with disagreements resolved through discussion.
Statistical analyses were implemented in R Studio 4.2.2 using the metafor package for frequentist meta-analysis and RoBMA for Robust Bayesian Meta-Analysis. A multilevel random-effects model was used to account for multiple dependent outcomes from the same studies. Between-measurement correlation was set at r = 0.3 based on available raw data from one included study.

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Search Strategy

PubMed: Search terms developed with assistance from academic librarians, targeting oxytocin administration studies with executive function outcomes
Europe PubMed Central: Customized search terms adapted for database specifications
Bielefeld Academic Search Engine (BASE): Comprehensive search strategy including grey literature and preprints

title: Effects of Oxytocin Administration on Non-Social Executive Functions in Humans: A Preregistered Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
text:
Study Characteristics

Included studies: The final meta-analysis included 13 studies with 20 effect estimates
Total participants: 729 (284 in within-participant studies, 445 in between-group studies)
Mean age: 31.64 years (within-participant studies), 25.68 years (between-group studies)
Oxytocin dosage: Predominantly 24 IU intranasal (76.92% of studies)
Administration routes: Intranasal (92.3%), oral (7.7%)
Publication status: 76.92% peer-reviewed articles, 23.07% letters to editor
Study designs: 6 within-participant, 7 between-group studies

title: Research tools and resources
text:
Additional Resources


PRISMA for Living Systematic Reviews
PRISMA for Living Systematic Reviews (LSR) is an extension of the PRISMA statement that provides guidance on reporting living systematic reviews and meta-analyses. It includes a checklist and flow diagram to help researchers ensure they are following best practices in their reporting.
Visit PRISMA-Statement.org Website


PROSPERO
PROSPERO is specifically designed for registering systematic review protocols focused on health related research It provides a standardized format for documenting review methods before they begin.
Visit PROSPERO


Open Science Framework (OSF)
The Open Science Framework (OSF) is a free and open-source platform that supports researchers in managing their projects, sharing their data, and collaborating with others. It provides tools for pre-registration, data sharing, and project management, making it easier for researchers to conduct and share their work transparently. It is developed by the Center for Open Science (COS).
Visit OSF


Retraction Watch
Tracking retractions as a window into the scientific process. This resource monitors and reports on retractions of scientific papers.
Visit Retraction Watch


Zotero
Reference management software that helps you collect, organize, and cite research. Zotero informs when articles in your libraries have been retracted or corrected, and it can help you keep track of your references and citations.
Visit Zotero

title: Standardization Framework for Living Meta-Analysis on AMORE
text:
Mandatory Requirements

Update Frequency
Maximum 24 months between analysis updates
Pre-registration
Meta-analysis must be pre-registered
Pre-print Publication
Initial results must be published on recognized pre-print server (e.g., Open Science Framework)
Guidelines Adherence
Must follow PRISMA or equivalent guidelines (MOOSE, MARS)
Data Repository
Meta-analysis data must be stored in recognized repository (e.g., Open Science Framework, Zenodo)
Analysis Scripts
Free software scripts must be deposited in recognized repository
Deviation Reporting
Supply deviation report with meta-analysis manuscript

title: Standardization Framework for Living Meta-Analysis on AMORE
text:
Recommended Practices

Accumulation Bias
Develop plan to address accumulation bias in frequentist framework
Effect Determination
Use Bayes factor of 10 to conclude presence/absence of effects
Null Hypothesis
Create plan to evaluate evidence for null hypothesis
Visualizations
Include forest plots and funnel plots
